# Get Started ## Definitions Term | Condition ---------|---------- **API** | Application Programming interface. A set of definitions, protocols, and tools that can be used to create applications, interact with other applications, and exchange data. **ASPSP** | Account Servicing Payment Service Provider. Payment service provider providing and maintaining a payment account for a payer. **AISP** | Account Information Service Provider. Provides account information services as an online service with consolidated information on one or more payment accounts held by a payment service user with one or more payment service provider(s). **eIDAS** | Electronic Identification, Authentication and trust Services. A set of standards for electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the European Single Market. **Provider** | Represents the ASPSP. A bank or financial institution that offer payment accounts with online access. **PSD2** | The Second Revised Payment Services Directive. The directive of the European Parliament and of the Council of the European Union which requires ﬁnancial institutions within the European Economic Area to provide access to their customers' accounts (XS2A), to Third Party Providers to provide account information and payment initiation services. **PSU** | Payment Service User. Natural or legal person making use of a payment service as a payee, payer or both. **PISP** | Payment Initiation Service Provider. Provides an online service to initiate a payment order at the request of the payment service user with respect to a payment account held at another payment service provider. **PIISP** | Payment Issuer Instrument Service Provider. Provides information about the funds availability of payment transactions based on the payment cards. The related services supplied can be identified as CAF/FCS (Confirmation on the Availability of Funds Service). **QSEAL** | Qualified Electronic Seal Certificate is a qualified digital certificate under the trust services defined in the eIDAS Regulation. **QWAC** | Qualified Certificate for Website Authentication - Used for two purposes: the verification of the parties, and their secure communications using Transport Layer Security Encryption. **SCA** | Strong Customer Authentication. Authentication based on the use of two or more elements designed in such a way as to protect the confidentiality of the authentication data. **TPP** | An entity authorised to access accounts on behalf of customers but that does not operate those accounts themselves. TPPs include PISPs, AISPs, and PIISPs. **XS2A** | Access to Account. The provision of secure access to accounts operated by ASPSPs using APIs. ### Scopes Definition Type | Description ---------|---------- **accounts** | grants TPP access to Customer's accounts data **transactions** | grants TPP access to transactions which belong to Customer's account **balances** | grants TPP access to Customer's balances data ## Registration Endpoint Endpoint | Verb | Purpose ---------|----------|---------- /api/v1/tpps | **POST** | Used for registration in Salt Edge PSD2 Compliance Dashboard. After registration, you will receive a letter of confirmation on your representative email. ## API Endpoints Endpoint | Verb | Purpose ---------|----------|---------- /api/v1/oauth/tokens | **POST** | Generate access and refresh tokens. /api/v1/consents | **POST** | This method creates a consent resource, defining access rights to dedicated accounts of a given `PSU-ID`. These accounts are addressed explicitly in the method as parameters as a core function. /api/v1/consents/{consent_id} | **GET** | Returns the content of an account information consent object. This returns the data for the TPP especially in cases, where the consent was directly managed between ASPSP and PSU e.g. in a redirect SCA Approach. /api/v1/consents/{consent_id}/status | **GET** | Read the status of an account information consent resource. /api/v1/consents/{consent_id} | **DELETE** | This method deletes a consent. /api/v1/accounts | **GET** | Read the identifiers of the available payment account together with booking balance information, depending on the consent granted. It is assumed that a consent of the PSU to this access is already given and stored on the ASPSP system. The addressed list of accounts depends on the PSU ID and the stored consent addressed by consentId. Returns all identifiers of the accounts, to which an account access has been granted to through the `/consents` endpoint by the PSU. In addition, relevant information about the accounts and hyperlinks to corresponding account information resources are provided if a related consent has been already granted. **Remark**: Note that the `/consents` endpoint optionally offers to grant an access on all available payment accounts of a PSU. In this case, this endpoint will deliver the information about all available payment accounts of the PSU at this ASPSP. /api/v1/refresh/consents/{consent_id} | **PUT** | This endpoint is responsible for starting the process of refreshing account information data on Bit PSD2 side. Due to asynchronous nature of this action, TPP has to poll the status of this process untill receive the status failed or finished /api/v1/refresh/consents/{consent_id} | **GET** | This endpoint is responsible for returning the current status of fetching account information process. /api/v1/accounts/{account_id} | **GET** | Reads details about an account, with balances where required. It is assumed that a consent of the PSU to this access is already given and stored on the ASPSP system. The addressed details of this account depends on the stored consent addressed by `consentId`. /api/v1/accounts/{account_id}/transactions | **GET** | Read transaction reports or transaction lists of a given account addressed by `account_id`, depending on the steering parameter `bookingStatus` together with balances. /api/v1/accounts/{account_id}/transactions/{transaction_id} | **GET** | Reads transaction data from a given account and transaction addressed by `account_id` and `transaction_id`. /api/v1/accounts/{account_id}/balances | **GET** | Reads account data from a given account addressed by `account_id`. ## All Errors During any request or flow originating either on TPP or Salt Edge PSD2 Compliance side, a number of errors may appear. In order to standardize errors while still giving some degree of freedom in explaining an error callback, parameters should include both `error_text` and `error_code`. Error message serves the purpose of communicating the issue to the Customer, whereas error class should be used by TPPs in order to be able to handle various scenarios. Contents of the error_code are entirely up to the Provider, they may even be localized. However, values sent within `error_text` parameter should be from the standardized list. This list may and will be extended over time. Class | Code | Description ---------|----------|---------- **FormatError** | 400 | Invalid input. More info in `error_message`. **DigestInvalid** | 400 | Header 'Digest' invalid. **SignatureInvalid** | 400 | Given signature is invalid. **SignatureMissing** | 400 | This request cannot be performed without Signature header. **SignatureMalformed** | 400 | Given signature is malformed. **CertificateInvalid** | 401 | Given certificate is invalid. **ConsentStatusForbidden** | 403 | Consent is not valid. **AccessDenied** | 403 | The resource owner or authorization server denied the request. **TppNotFound** | 404 | Requested TPP cannot be found. **ConsentNotFound** | 404 | Requested consent cannot be found. **AccountNotFound** | 404 | Requested account cannot be found. **TransactionNotFound** | 404 | Requested transaction cannot be found. **RouteNotFound** | 404 | Requested url does not exist. ## Useful Links and Contact Information You can find below the following useful links and assistance channel: 1. You can find the full documentation for the [BOI NextGenPSD2 Implementation Guidelines](https://www.boi.org.il/roles/supervisionregulation/bank-sup/open-banking/) on the official BOI website. 2. In case you have any questions on integration with this dedicated interface please contact us at: compliance@saltedge.com or use the Help Desk from TPP Dashboard. ## Account Information Flow 1. Request consent from the Bank BIT account's owner to share with you information on one or more of their accounts. 2. **Customer Authentication and Customer consent approval**: Consent is created once the bank's customer authenticates himself on the Bank BIT login page and explicitly approves the consent sent by you to a dedicated screen. Changing the user's password during the customer consent process, is not applicable. **When the customer is authenticated and the consent is approved, you will receive an authorisation code, which must be immediately replaced with an Access Token.** 3. **Retrieve account information**: You can retrieve the bank customer's account data as long as the consent is valid and has not expired, and by providing the valid Access Token. 4. **Consent Renewal**. If the consent has expired or been revoked for any reason, your customer can give you a new consent. ## Consent statuses |Description|Berlingroup Status| |---|---| |The consent data have been received and are technically correct.
The data is not authorised yet.|received| |The consent data have been rejected e.g. since no successful
authorisation has taken place.|rejected| |The consent is accepted and valid for GET account data calls
and others as specified in the consent object.|valid| |The consent expired.| expired | |The consent has been revoked by the PSU towards the ASPSP.| revokedByPsu | |The corresponding TPP has terminated the consent by
applying the DELETE method to the consent resource.| terminatedByTpp| |The consent has been suspended by the ASPSP, according
to requirements that are detailed in BoI's directive.| suspendedByASPSP | ## Payment statuses |Description|Berlingroup Status| |---|---| |Payment initiation or individual transaction included in the payment
initiationis pending. Further checks and status update will be performed.|PDNG| |All preceding checks such as technical validation andcustomer profile
were successful and therefore the payment initiation has been accepted
for execution.|ACSP| |Settlement on the debtor’s account has been completed.|ACSC| |Payment initiation has been received by the receiving agent.|RCVD| |Payment initiation or individual transaction included in the payment initiation has been rejected.| RJCT | |Beneficiary did not respond. Ordered expired within 3 days payment
initiation hasbeen rejected.| EXPD | |Payment initiation has been cancelled before execution.| CANC | # Authorization Security ## OAuth2 URLs URL | Description ---------|---------- `https://www.bitpay.co.il/app/open-banking` | Authorization URL `https://open-banking.bitpay.co.il/api/v1/oauth/token` | Token URL `https://open-banking.bitpay.co.il/api/v1/oauth/token` | Token Refresh URL > In accordance with the relevant RFCs, the token and token revocation URLs will only accept a content type of `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`. JSON content is not permitted and will return an error. ## OAuth2 Scopes Name | Description ---------|---------- `AIS:{consentId}` | Allows to consume the resources referenced to Consent with specified `Id` `PIS:{paymentId}` | Allows to consume the resources referenced to Payment with specified `Id` ## State and Security Before we dive into the semantics of the different OAuth2 grants, we should stop and discuss security, specifically the use of the state parameter. Cross-site request forgery, or CSRF, and Clickjacking are security vulnerabilities that must be addressed by individuals implementing OAuth. This is typically accomplished using the state parameter. state is sent in the authorization request and returned back in the response and should be a value that binds the user's request to their authenticated state. For example, state could be a hash of the user's session cookie, or some other nonce that can be linked to the user's session. When a user begins an authorization flow on the client, a state is generated that is unique to that user's request. This value is stored somewhere only accessible to the client and the user, i.e. protected by the same-origin policy. When the user is redirected, the state parameter is returned. The client validates the request by checking that the state returned matches the stored value. If they match, it is a valid authorization request. If they do not match, it's possible that someone intercepted the request or otherwise falsely authorized themselves to another user's resources, and the request should be denied. ## Authorization Code Grant The authorization code grant is what most developers will recognize as "standard OAuth2" and involves retrieving an access code and exchanging it for a user's access token. It allows the authorization server to act as an intermediary between the client and the resource owner, so the resource owner's credentials are never shared directly with the client. ## PKCE PKCE modifies the standard authorization code grant. Before starting the authorization code grant, a random string called `code_verifier` is generated using the characters: `[A-Z], [a-z], [0-9], "-", ".", "_"` and `"~"`, with a minimum length of 43 characters and a maximum length of 128 characters. Additionally to the `code_verifier` a `code_challenge` is created. We supports `code_challenge_method` `S256` the code_challenge is the SHA256 Hash value of the code_verifier url safe base64 encoded (without trailing "=" compare to: [https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7636#appendix-A](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7636#appendix-A)) ## Authorization URL Example ``` https://www.bitpay.co.il/app/open-banking?response_type=code&client_id=org-identifier-123456&scope=AIS:2345&state=15773059ghq9183habn&redirect_uri=https%3A%2F%2Ftpp.website&code_challenge=XEuwH6eFPlLDoVB7vL3KpC6T3WYaEGDyXGb7tpNJCZA&code_challenge_method=S256 ``` `client_id` is TPP's organization identifier.`scope` is a scope specified in [OAuth2 Scopes](#section/Authorization-Security/OAuth2-Scopes). `redirect_uri` is whatever URL you registered when creating your application, url-encoded. `state` is the unique string mentioned in [State and Security](#section/Authorization-Security/State-and-Security). `code_challenge` and `code_challenge_method` described in [PKCE](#section/Authorization-Security/PKCE) ## Redirect URL Example ``` https://tpp.website/?code=NhhvTDYsFcdgNLnnLijcl7Ku7bEEeee&state=15773059ghq9183habn ``` `code` is now exchanged for the user's access token by making a POST request to the [Token URL](#tag/OAuth2/operation/post-api-oauth-tokens) ## Signature Headers #### Instruction to create BerlinGroup Signature To register as a TPP, the first thing you must do is get a valid EIDAS certificate.
The required headers for this call are: - `X-Request-ID`: [A Universally Unique IDentifier (UUID) URN Namespace](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4122) - example: `79c851ce-f543-4c27-a8e4-f9aad20724ba` - `Digest`: Base64 request body encoded SHA256 - Example: ```bash > export BODY="{}" > echo -n $BODY | openssl sha256 -binary | base64 RBNvo1WzZ4oRRq0W9+hknpT7T8If536DEMBg9hyq/4o= # Digest value: "SHA-256=RBNvo1WzZ4oRRq0W9+hknpT7T8If536DEMBg9hyq/4o=" ``` - `Date`: [Date/Time Format](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7231#section-7.1.1.1) - Example: `Fri, 04 Feb 2022 17:16:59 GMT` - `TPP-Signature-Certificate`: Base64 strict encoded certificate in PEM format. - Example: ```bash > export PEM="-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----\nMB0wFgIBADAAMAAwBB8AHwAwADAFMAADAQAwAAMBAA==\n-----END CERTIFICATE-----\n" > echo -n $PEM | base64 LS0tLS1CRUdJTiBDRVJUSUZJQ0FURS0tLS0tCk1CMHdGZ0lCQURBQU1BQXdCQjhBSHdBd0FEQUZNQUFEQVFBd0FBTUJBQT09Ci0tLS0tRU5EIENFUlRJRklDQVRFLS0tLS0K ``` - `Signature`: Is the signed value of the message, and has the following regexp structure: ```bash /keyId=\"SN=(?.+),CA=(?.+)\",algorithm=\"(?.+)\",headers=\"(?.+)\",signature=\"(?.+)\"/ ``` - `keyId` that must be formatted as `SN={serial},CA={issuer}` - `algorithm` could be (`"rsa-sha-256"` or `"rsa-sha-512"`) - `headers`.
Create a string to be using a set of request headers: `digest`, `x-request-id`, `psu-id`, `psu-corporate-id` and `tpp-redirect-uri` in this example, we will just use the mandatory ones: `x-request-id` and `digest`, the final result will be: `"x-request-id digest"` - `signature`
Create a string to be signed built using a set of request headers: `digest`, `x-request-id`, `psu-id`, `psu-corporate-id` and `tpp-redirect-uri` in this example, we will just use the mandatory ones: `x-request-id` and`digest`, the final result will be: `"digest x-request-id"`.
Here the order of these fields in the signing string matters and they need to be on separate lines. The order has to be exactly as in `headers`.
You should generate a signature value that must be base-64 encoded: ```bash # // order as in 'headers' ("x-request-id digest") > export SIGNING_STRING="x-request-id: 79c851ce-f543-4c27-a8e4-f9aad20724ba\ndigest: SHA-256=RBNvo1WzZ4oRRq0W9+hknpT7T8If536DEMBg9hyq/4o=\n" > printf $SIGNING_STRING | openssl dgst -sha256 -sign certificate_private_key.pem | openssl base64 -A  ``` - As result the signature value should be as: ```json "Signature": keyId="SN=B83852160,CA=FIRMA PROFESIONAL",algorithm="rsa-sha-256",headers="x-request-id digest",signature="" ``` **The signed request should be as:** ```http POST /api/berlingroup/v1/tpp/certificates HTTP/1.1 Host: priora.saltedge.com Content-Type: application/json Date: Fri, 04 Feb 2022 17:16:59 GMT Digest: SHA-256=RBNvo1WzZ4oRRq0W9+hknpT7T8If536DEMBg9hyq/4o= X-Request-ID: 79c851ce-f543-4c27-a8e4-f9aad20724ba Signature: keyId="SN=B83852160,CA=FIRMA PROFESIONAL",algorithm="rsa-sha-256",headers="x-request-id digest",signature="" TPP-Signature-Certificate: LS0tLS1CRUdJTiBDRVJUSUZJQ0FURS0tLS0tCk1CMHdGZ0lCQURBQU1BQXdCQjhBSHdBd0FEQUZNQUFEQVFBd0FBTUJBQT09Ci0tLS0tRU5EIENFUlRJRklDQVRFLS0tLS0K {} ``` # Legal information ## Term of use Welcome to Bit Developers Portal by Bank Hapoalim (together with its subdomains, Content, Marks, Documentation and services, the **“Site”**). No waiver of any term of these Terms shall be deemed a further or continuing waiver of such term or any other term, and a party's failure to assert any right or provision under these Terms shall not constitute a waiver of such right or provision. **Last updated: December 2024** ## Service Level Policy 1. **Support services and inquiry handling** a. The support center for BIT's third-party providers (TPPs) operates from Monday to Friday between 09:00 to 18:00 (‘business hours'), in the support channels detailed in this section. Support is provided during the business hours detailed in this section. Inquiries outside the support channels detailed in this section will not be answered in accordance with the policy detailed in section 5. b. The email address to open a request to the support center is compliance@saltedge.com, or you submit the request directly via TPP Dashboard > Support Center. c. Support services will be provided to third party providers who are active in the Sandbox or Production environment. 2. **Handling of new inquiries from third party providers** a. To make an inquiry, the applicant must provide the following two identifiers: (1) the serial number of the certificate they received from the regulator, and (2) the company number (ח.פ) of the third-party provider. After proper identification, the support center will ask for the contact's name and phone number to record who contacted on behalf of the third-party provider (by phone or email, as the case may be). b. The initial response to an inquiry via email as described in section 4 'Classification of inquiries and their treatment' period following the inquiry as defined in the section 'Support services and inquiry handling'. c. Support services and the handling of inquiries received by email outside of 'business hours' will be handled at the beginning of the next business day, as described in section 'Support services and inquiry handling'. d. Contact us by email incident@saltedge.com 4. **Classification of inquiries and their treatment** | Inquiry Classification | Definition | Update of Inquiry's Status| |-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | 1 | Any malfunction in the system, which, in the bank's opinion, disables or substantially interferes with the open banking activity. | Immediately and once every few hours depending on progress in treating the problem. | | 2 | Any error, defect, disruption including a decrease and/or change in system performance. | Once every two days until an end date is defined for handling the inquiry. | | 3 | A point fault with a limited effect on system users. This method creates a consent resource, defining access rights to dedicated accounts of a given PSU-ID. These accounts are addressed explicitly in the method as parameters as a core function.

**Consent access details**

Consent can be one of the following models:

- **Bank offered** - with bank driven account selection and possible restriction to account types 
- **Detailed** - with pre-selected accounts on TPP side

*Bank offered consent*

The bank offered consent model would allow for PSU to select accounts to be shared with TPP on ASPSP side after authentication, while TPP shall pre-define only the permissions (accounts, balances, transactions) required to provide service. In this case, access remains empty until the SCA process is finalized and the consent status changes to ‘valid’. Both structures exhibit similar behavior. Both structures exhibit similar behavior.

Structure example 1:

```json
 { // Access to accounts, balances, transactions data  
  "access": {
    "accounts": [],
    "transactions": [],
    "balances": []
  }
}
```
Structure example 2:

```json
 { // Access to accounts and balances data (accounts access automatically included)
  "access":  {
    "balances": []
  }
}
```

*Bank offered consent with restrictions*

In case the TPP wants PSU to select accounts on the ASPSP side, but for this specific TPP service the consent shall be restricted to the specific account type.

Structure example:

```json
{ // Consent restricted to savings account(s) selected by PSU 
  "access": {
    "accounts": [],
    "transactions": [],
    "balances": [],
    "restrictedTo": ["SVGS"] 
  }
}
```

**NOTE**: The `restrictedTo` attribute appears only in the **POST** `/consents` request body. According to the Berlin Group standard, this attribute should not appear in the response of **POST** `/consents` or **GET** `/consents`


*Detailed consent (pre-selected accounts)*

The detailed consent model presumes for PSU to grant access to the specific accounts allowed the TPP to fetch. For this, the PSU selects accounts from a pre-saved list in TPP application or provides account(s) details directly in the TPP application before redirection for authentication. In this case, the ASPSP should validate and allow access only to the requested information in the consent details, with a set of applicable data permissions (accounts, balances, transactions).

Structure example:

```json
 {
  "access": { 
    "accounts": [
      { // Account information of the following payment account only in USD currency
        "bban": "5411241",
        "currency": "USD",
        "cashAccountType": "CACC"
      }
    ],
    "transactions": [
      { // Transactions and account info of the following savings account
        "bban": "5411241",
        "cashAccountType": "SVGS"
      }
    ],
    "balances": [
      { // ILS balance and account info of the following payment account 
        "bban": "123123",
        "currency": "ILS",
      }
    ]
  }
}
```

Might be ignored if a delta function is used or if bookingStatus equals "information". For booked transactions, the relevant date is the booking date. For pending transactions, the relevant date is the entry date, which may not be transparent neither in this API nor other channels of the ASPSP. If the bookingStatus equals "all", this date might be ignored for all transactions referred to by bookingStatus "information".

dateTo.name: dateTo
dateTo.description: End date (inclusive the data dateTo) of the transaction list, default is "now" if not given. Might be ignored if a delta function is used. For booked transactions, the relevant date is the booking date. For pending transactions, the relevant date is the entry date, which may not be transparent neither in this API nor other channels of the ASPSP. If the bookingStatus equals "all", this date might be ignored for all transactions referred to by bookingStatus "information".

entryReferenceFrom.name: entryReferenceFrom
entryReferenceFrom.description: This data attribute is indicating that the AISP is in favour to get all transactions after the transaction with identification entryReferenceFrom alternatively to the above defined period. This is a implementation of a delta access. If this data element is contained, the entries "dateFrom" and "dateTo" might be ignored by the ASPSP if a delta report is supported.

bookingStatus.name: bookingStatus
bookingStatus.description: Permitted codes are "booked", "pending",  "both", "information" and "all". "booked" shall be supported by the ASPSP. To support the "pending" and "both" feature is optional for the ASPSP, Error code if not supported in the online banking frontend. If supported, "both" means to request transaction reports of transaction of bookingStatus either "pending" or "booked". To support the "information" feature is optional for the ASPSP. Currently the booking status “information” only covers standing orders. Error code if not supported. To support the "all" feature is optional for the ASPSP, Error code if not supported. If supported, "all" means to request transaction reports of transaction of any bookingStatus ("pending", "booked" or "information").

deltaList.name: deltaList
deltaList.description: This data attribute is indicating that the AISP is in favour to get all transactions after the last report access for this PSU on the addressed account. This is another implementation of a delta access-report. This delta indicator might be rejected by the ASPSP if this function is not supported. If this data element is contained, the entries "dateFrom" and "dateTo" might be ignored by the ASPSP if a delta report is supported.

transaction_id.name: transaction_id
transaction_id.description: This identification is given by the attribute transactionId of the  corresponding entry of a transaction list.

PSU-ID-Type.name: PSU-ID-Type
PSU-ID-Type.description: Type of the PSU-ID, needed in scenarios where PSUs have several PSU-IDs as access possibility.

PSU-Corporate-ID-Type.name: PSU-Corporate-ID-Type
PSU-Corporate-ID-Type.description: Only used in a corporate context.

PSU-IP-Address-required.name: PSU-IP-Address
PSU-IP-Address-required.description: The forwarded IP Address header field consists of the corresponding HTTP request IP Address field between PSU and TPP. If not available, the TPP shall use the IP Address used by the TPP when submitting this request.

Accept.name: Accept
Accept.description: The TPP can indicate the formats of account reports supported together with a priorisation following the HTTP header definition. Only JSON value is supported

PSU-IP-Address-OnlyPsu.name: PSU-IP-Address
PSU-IP-Address-OnlyPsu.description:
The forwarded IP Address header field consists of the corresponding HTTP request IP Address field between PSU and TPP. It shall be contained if and only if this request was actively initiated by the PSU.

saving_account_id.description: This identification is denoting the addressed savings account. The savings-account-id is retrieved by using a "Read Savings Account List" call. The savings-account-id is the "resourceId" attribute of the account structure. Its value is constant at least throughout the lifecycle of a given consent.
